content: Some days ago, it happened that there were two simalteneous things in my mind: attraction and Lawvere metric spaces. I was not so much thinking to gravitational attraction but to attraction between people: if you have two people xxx and yyy and if you denote d(x,y)d(x,y)d(x,y) the attraction generated by yyy on xxx, then it is clearly not a symmetric function but it still somehow a distance between two people. And I'm always thinking to this fact: human or social sciences are too much complicated for mathematics because they involve less obvious dynamics. But there is some dynamic: maybe attraction between people creates somehow very complicated dynamical systems. People who despise mathematics say it all the time: things are not black or white etc... and they are not wrong but what they don't know is that the mathematics behind human life phenomena are probably even more complicated or as complicated but different than classical mathematics used in physics. For instance, we struggle to understand economics and they generate interesting new topics like game theory etc... But, well, it's easier to think to attraction between planets (for instance) first because it is something that we know better.

Definition: Consider the set X=R3X=\mathbb{R}^3X=R3. Define a function m:R3→[0,∞)m:\mathbb{R}^3 \rightarrow [0,\infty)m:R3→[0,∞) which will give the mass
m(x,y,z)m_{(x,y,z)}m(x,y,z)​ of a single object at (x,y,z)(x,y,z)(x,y,z). If there is no object at (x,y,z)(x,y,z)(x,y,z), then m(x,y,z)=0m_{(x,y,z)}=0m(x,y,z)​=0.

Denote d:X×X→[0,∞)d:X\times X \rightarrow [0,\infty)d:X×X→[0,∞) the euclidean metric.

If a,b∈R3a,b \in \mathbb{R}^3a,b∈R3 are such that a≠ba \neq ba=b, denote the acceleration (and not the force) generated by the object at bbb on the object at aaa by (without the GGG):

ρ(a,b)=mbd(a,b)2\rho(a,b)=\frac{m_{b}}{d(a,b)^2}ρ(a,b)=d(a,b)2mb​​

Define ρ(a,a)=0\rho(a,a)=0ρ(a,a)=0 (the object at aaa doesn't generate any acceleration on itself).

Proposition: (X,ρ)(X,\rho)(X,ρ) is a Lawvere metric space.

  • ρ(a,a)=0\rho(a,a)=0ρ(a,a)=0 is true by definition (and this definition is the natural one)

  • The triangular inequality is verified:

If a,b,ca,b,ca,b,c are three distinct points in XXX, then:

ρ(a,c)=mcd(a,c)2≤ρ(a,b)+ρ(a,c)=mbd(a,b)2+mcd(b,c)2ρ(a,c)=\frac{m_c}{d(a,c)^2}\le ρ(a,b)+ρ(a,c)=\frac{m_b}{d(a,b)^2}+\frac{m_c}{d(b,c)^2}ρ(a,c)=d(a,c)2mc​​≤ρ(a,b)+ρ(a,c)=d(a,b)2mb​​+d(b,c)2mc​​
​
Proof: To see this, simply note that d(a,c)2=d(a,b)2+d(b,c)2d(a,c)^2=d(a,b)^2+d(b,c)^2d(a,c)2=d(a,b)2+d(b,c)2 (edit: no, only if the objects are the vertices of a right triangle...), and thus ρ(a,c)=mcd(a,b)2+d(b,c)2≤mcd(b,c)2\rho(a,c)=\frac{m_c}{d(a,b)^2+d(b,c)^2} \le \frac{m_c}{d(b,c)^2}ρ(a,c)=d(a,b)2+d(b,c)2mc​​≤d(b,c)2mc​​.

Remarks:

  • The separation property is not verified because ρ(a,b)=0\rho(a,b)=0ρ(a,b)=0 if mb=0m_b=0mb​=0.
  • The symmetry is not verified because ρ(a,b)≠ρ(b,a)\rho(a,b) \neq \rho(b,a)ρ(a,b)=ρ(b,a) if a,ba,ba,b are two distinct points such that ma≠mbm_a \neq m_bma​=mb​.
  • The only usual property of a distance which is not required in the definition of a Lawvere metric space and which is verified is that ρ(a,b)<∞\rho(a,b) < \inftyρ(a,b)<∞. But in fact, I think that maybe the construction can be generalized by replacing XXX by any "metric space" where the metric ddd is like a usual metric but with values in [0,∞][0,\infty][0,∞] and which verifies not only the triangular inequality but also the stronger d(a,c)2≤d(a,b)2+d(b,c)2d(a,c)^2 \le d(a,b)^2+d(b,c)^2d(a,c)2≤d(a,b)2+d(b,c)2. Like this, we would obtain a fully general Lawvere metric.

I'm not sure what I want to ask. Have you already thought to that, read something like that or do you find it interesting? I don't know lot of physics but it sounds interesting to me. I'm sure that by following this idea, we could go much further. Probably I would be happy with any kind of conversation related to that.

This is fun! It makes me think of a related question. Let d:X×X→[0,∞]d: X \times X \to [0, \infty]d:X×X→[0,∞] be the distance function of a Lawvere metric space, so that:

  • d(x,x)=0d(x,x)=0d(x,x)=0 for all x∈Xx \in Xx∈X
  • d(x,y)+d(y,z)≥d(x,z)d(x,y)+d(y,z) \geq d(x,z)d(x,y)+d(y,z)≥d(x,z) for all x,y,z∈Xx,y,z \in Xx,y,z∈X

And let f:[0,∞]→[0,∞]f: [0, \infty] \to [0, \infty]f:[0,∞]→[0,∞] be a function.

Finally, let ρ:X×X→[0,∞]\rho: X \times X \to [0, \infty]ρ:X×X→[0,∞] be the following function: ρ(x,y)=f(d(x,y))\rho(x,y) = f(d(x,y))ρ(x,y)=f(d(x,y)) for all x,y∈Xx,y \in Xx,y∈X. So, ρ=f∘d\rho = f \circ dρ=f∘d.

Then, what are some functions fff so that ρ\rhoρ is a distance function of a Lawvere metric space?
If f(0)=0f(0)=0f(0)=0, fff is increasing and f(x+y)≤f(x)+f(y)f(x+y) \le f(x) + f(y)f(x+y)≤f(x)+f(y), it will work.

We first check that ρ(x,x)=0\rho(x,x) = 0ρ(x,x)=0 for all x∈Xx \in Xx∈X:

  • ρ(x,x)=f(d(x,x))=f(0)=0\rho(x,x) = f(d(x,x)) = f(0) = 0ρ(x,x)=f(d(x,x))=f(0)=0

Now we check that ρ(x,y)+ρ(y,z)≥ρ(x,z)\rho(x,y) + \rho(y,z) \geq \rho(x,z)ρ(x,y)+ρ(y,z)≥ρ(x,z) for all x,y,z∈Xx,y,z \in Xx,y,z∈X:

  • ρ(x,y)+ρ(y,z)=f(d(x,y))+f(d(y,z))≥f(d(x,y)+d(y,z))\rho(x,y) + \rho(y,z) = f(d(x,y)) + f(d(y,z)) \geq f(d(x,y) + d(y,z))ρ(x,y)+ρ(y,z)=f(d(x,y))+f(d(y,z))≥f(d(x,y)+d(y,z))
  • We know that d(x,y)+d(y,z)≥d(x,z)d(x,y) + d(y,z) \geq d(x,z)d(x,y)+d(y,z)≥d(x,z). Since fff is increasing that means that f(d(x,z)+d(y,z))≥f(d(x,z))=ρ(x,z)f(d(x,z) + d(y,z)) \geq f(d(x,z)) = \rho(x,z)f(d(x,z)+d(y,z))≥f(d(x,z))=ρ(x,z).
  • So we conclude ρ(x,y)+ρ(y,z)≥ρ(x,z)\rho(x,y) + \rho(y,z) \geq \rho(x,z)ρ(x,y)+ρ(y,z)≥ρ(x,z), as desired.
Interestingly, the requirements on fff seem at least similar to the definition of a "(lax) monoidal monotone" from here, page 55.

Yes, it a functor from the monoidal category [0,∞][0,\infty][0,∞] to it self where an arrow x→yx \rightarrow yx→y is an equality x≤yx \le yx≤y, the identity at xxx is x≤xx \le xx≤x and the tensor product is given by addition. However, I'm not sure it is a monoidal functor...
Oh no, an oplax monoidal functor is one such that f(x+y)≤f(x)+f(y)f(x+y) \le f(x) + f(y)f(x+y)≤f(x)+f(y) and f(0)≤0f(0)\le 0f(0)≤0 if I'm not mistaken
